abstract.text: A template that describes available predicates and how to display them.

inlineContent.text: You can create instances of

programmatically or in Interface Builder. By default, a noncompound row template has three views: a popup (or static text field) on the left, a popup or static text field for operators, and either a popup or other view on the right.  You can subclass
to create a row template with different numbers or types of views.
is a concrete class, but it has five primitive methods that are called by
, and
implements all of these methods, but you can override them for custom templates. The primitive methods are used by an instance of
as follows.
First, an instance of
is created, and some row templates are set on it—either through a nib file or programmatically. The first thing predicate editor does is ask each of the templates for their views, using
After setting up the predicate editor, you typically send it a
message to restore a saved predicate.
needs to determine which of its templates should display each predicate in the predicate tree. It does this by sending each of its row templates a
message and choosing the one that returns the highest value.
After finding the best match for a predicate,
copies that template to get fresh views, inserts them into the proper row, and then sets the predicate on the template using
. Within that method, the
object must set its views’ values to represent that predicate.
next asks the template for the “displayable sub-predicates” of the predicate by sending a
message. If a template represents a predicate in its entirety, or if the predicate has no subpredicates, it can return
for this.  Otherwise, it should return a list of predicates to be made into sub-rows of that template’s row. The whole process repeats for each sub-predicate.
At this point, the user sees the predicate that was saved.  If the user then makes some changes to the views of the templates, this causes

to recompute its predicate by asking each of the templates to return the predicate represented by the new view values, passing in the subpredicates represented by the sub-rows (an empty array if there are none, or
if they aren’t supported by that predicate type):

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
The value of the receiver’s cell as an Objective-C object.
A defined set of rules that allows the editing of predicate objects.
The row templates for the receiver.
A template that describes available predicates and how to display them.
Returns the compound predicate types.
Returns the subpredicates that should be made sub-rows of a given predicate.
Initializes and returns a row template suitable for displaying compound predicates.
Initializes and returns a “pop-up-pop-up-view”–style row template.
Initializes and returns a “pop-up-pop-up-pop-up”–style row template.
Returns the left hand expressions for the receiver.
Returns a positive number if the receiver can represent a given predicate, and
if it cannot.
Returns the comparison predicate modifier for the receiver.
Returns the array of comparison predicate operators.
Returns the comparison predicate options.
Returns the predicate represented by the receiver’s views’ values and the given sub-predicates.
Returns the attribute type of the receiver’s right expression.
Returns the right hand expressions for the receiver.
Sets the value of the views according to the given predicate.
Returns the views that display this template’s predicate.
Returns an array of predicate templates for the given attribute key paths for a given entity.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
